Class ArgumentParser

extends java.lang.Object

      This is the default constructor.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addArg(java.lang.String name)
      This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling the main constructor by providing a blank string for a description and defaulting the argument to type string.
      void addArg(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String description)
      This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling main constructor by providing the name and description, provided by the user, and defaulting the type to string.
      void addArg(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String description, Argument.Type type)
      This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling main constructor by providing the name, description, and type of argument, as provided by the user.
      void addNamedArg(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String shortName, java.lang.String description, Argument.Type type, java.lang.String defaultValue)
      This method adds a named argument by adding it to the args list and to the NamedArgs class.
      void addPosArg(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String description, Argument.Type type, java.lang.String position)
      This method adds a positional argument by adding it to the args list and to the PosArgs class.
      void checkArgsThenParse(java.lang.String[] arr)
      This method checks for the named arguments, assigns their default values, and removes the arguments from the array of arguments.
      java.lang.String getAllPosArgNames()
      This method is called by various methods to return the names of all the positional arguments in the list.
      Argument getArg(int index)
      This method returns the name of the argument from the args list with at the specified index.
      java.lang.String getArg(java.lang.String unit)
      This method is called by the user and is used to return the value of an argument.
      java.lang.String getHelp()
      This method is called when the user enters --help or -h.
      int getNumArguments()
      This method returns the size of the args list, which represents the number of total arguments provided by the user.
      java.lang.String invalidValueMessage()
      This method is called when the user enters an invalid value for an argument.
      void parse(java.lang.String[] cla)
      This method parses through the values provided by the user and assigns these values to the positional arguments.
      void parseArgs(java.lang.String[] arr)
      This method is to be called by the user.
      java.lang.String writeArgsAsXML()
      This method is used in the save method of XMLTools.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArgumentParser

        public ArgumentParser()
        This is the default constructor. The user calls this if they do not specify a name and purpose for the program they are using.

      • ArgumentParser

        public ArgumentParser(java.lang.String n,
                      java.lang.String p)
        This constructor creates a new instance of the ArgumentParser class when called.
        Parameters:
        n - specifies the name of the program, as provided by the user.
        p - specifies the description of the program, as provided by the user.

    • Method Detail

      • getArg

        public Argument getArg(int index)
        This method returns the name of the argument from the args list with at the specified index.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the argument being returned.
        Returns:
        the argument at the index.

      • getNumArguments

        public int getNumArguments()
        This method returns the size of the args list, which represents the number of total arguments provided by the user.
        Returns:
        the size of the args list.

      • addArg

        public void addArg(java.lang.String name)
        This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling the main constructor by providing a blank string for a description and defaulting the argument to type string.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the argument.

      • addArg

        public void addArg(java.lang.String name,
                   java.lang.String description)
        This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling main constructor by providing the name and description, provided by the user, and defaulting the type to string.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the argument.
        description - the description of said argument.

      • addArg

        public void addArg(java.lang.String name,
                   java.lang.String description,
                   Argument.Type type)
        This method adds the argument provided to the list by calling main constructor by providing the name, description, and type of argument, as provided by the user.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the argument.
        description - the description of said argument.
        type - the type of argument.

      • addNamedArg

        public void addNamedArg(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.String shortName,
                        java.lang.String description,
                        Argument.Type type,
                        java.lang.String defaultValue)
        This method adds a named argument by adding it to the args list and to the NamedArgs class.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the argument.
        shortName - the short name version of the argument, such as 't' instead of "type."
        description - the description of said argument.
        type - the type of argument.
        defaultValue - the user specified default value of the named argument.

      • addPosArg

        public void addPosArg(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String description,
                      Argument.Type type,
                      java.lang.String position)
        This method adds a positional argument by adding it to the args list and to the PosArgs class.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the argument.
        description - the description of said argument.
        type - the type of argument.
        position - the position in the args list the argument goes

      • parse

        public void parse(java.lang.String[] cla)
        This method parses through the values provided by the user and assigns these values to the positional arguments.
        Parameters:
        cla - the values to be assigned to the positional arguments.
        Throws:
        TooFewArgsException - this exception is thrown when too few arguments are provided by the user.
        TooManyArgsException - this exception is thrown when too many arguments are provided by the user.
        InvalidValueException - this exception is thrown when the user provides a value of the wrong type for an argument.

      • getArg

        public java.lang.String getArg(java.lang.String unit)
        This method is called by the user and is used to return the value of an argument.
        Parameters:
        unit - the name of the argument to search for.
        Returns:
        the value of the argument.
        Throws:
        ArgumentNotFoundException - thrown when the argument doesn't exist.

      • getAllPosArgNames

        public java.lang.String getAllPosArgNames()
        This method is called by various methods to return the names of all the positional arguments in the list.
        Returns:
        the names of all positional arguments.

      • getHelp

        public java.lang.String getHelp()
        This method is called when the user enters --help or -h. When called, a message with information on the program is displayed.
        Returns:
        the help message.

      • invalidValueMessage

        public java.lang.String invalidValueMessage()
        This method is called when the user enters an invalid value for an argument.
        Returns:
        the error message for the InvalidValueException.

      • parseArgs

        public void parseArgs(java.lang.String[] arr)
        This method is to be called by the user. It should be called by the user instead of parse. This method calls checkArgsThenParse. It is mainly here for something the user can call easier instead of checkArgsThenParse because it has a shorter name.
        Parameters:
        arr - an array with values for arguments provided by the user.

      • checkArgsThenParse

        public void checkArgsThenParse(java.lang.String[] arr)
        This method checks for the named arguments, assigns their default values, and removes the arguments from the array of arguments. It then calls parse for the positional arguments left to be assigned values.
        Parameters:
        arr - an array with values for arguments provided by the user.
        Throws:
        GetHelpException - an exception called when the user wants the help message. Thrown when --help or -h is provided by the user.
        ArgumentNotFoundException - an exception thrown when the user provides a long-form or a short-name argument that doesn't exist in the list of arguments.

      • writeArgsAsXML

        public java.lang.String writeArgsAsXML()
        This method is used in the save method of XMLTools. This method converts the arguments and their values into a format to be used in an XML file.
        Returns:
        a string containing the arguments and their info in a format suitable for an XML file.
